text: Louis Henry Sullivan (September 3, 1856 - April 14, 1924) was an American architect. He was born in Boston, Massachusetts. Many people call him the creator of the modern skyscraper. Along with Henry Hobson Richardson and Frank Lloyd Wright, he is one of "the recognized trinity of American architecture.James F. O'Gorman, Three American Architects: Richardson, Sullivan, and Wright, 1865-1915 (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1991), p. xv He was a critic at the Chicago School. Sullivan was also a mentor to Frank Lloyd Wright.Gretchen Will Mayo, Frank Lloyd Wright (Milwaukee, WI: World Almanac Library, 2004), p. 18 He died in Chicago. He is buried in Graceland Cemetery in Uptown, Chicago. == References == Category:1856 births Category:1924 deaths Category:Burials at Graceland Cemetery Category:American architects Category:Businesspeople from Boston Category:19th-century architects
